page.title: 01WEST CALDER IN THE BEGINNING
page.content: WEST CALDER West Calder is a small town in the central belt of Scotland.It also gives its name to the surrounding district, including Polbeth and Harburn,the other centres of population in the area. There is evidence of settlement here as far back as the twelfth century when a stone church was built, probably replacing an earlier wooden building. On the drove road used to take cattle to market West Calder was a stopping place for drovers over the centuries which preceded the building of the railway.In the eighteen - seventies James (Paraffin) Young brought the shale-oil industry to West Lothian with the result that the population of the village,in common with many others,leapt.Houses were hurriedly erected for the incoming miners.These have now been replaced.
